workflow.name: Retweet cleanup with scheduling for X/Twitter
workflow.description:
## Who‚Äôs it for

Social media managers, creators, and brand accounts that rely on retweets for reach but want an automated, hands-off cleanup after campaigns to keep profiles tidy and on-brand.

## What it does / How it works

On a schedule, the workflow resolves your handle to a user ID, fetches recent tweets, filters **retweets only**, and safely unretweets them using batching and delays to respect rate limits. A dedicated **CONFIG (Set Fields)** node centralizes variables (e.g., `target_username`, `max_results`, `batch_delay_minutes`) so you can adjust behavior without touching logic.

## API endpoints used

* **GET** `/2/users/by/username/{username}` ‚Äì resolve handle ‚Üí user ID
* **GET** `/2/users/{id}/tweets?tweet.fields=created_at,referenced_tweets` ‚Äì fetch recent tweets (identify retweets via `referenced_tweets.type === "retweeted"`)
* **DELETE** `/2/users/{id}/retweets/{tweet_id}` ‚Äì unretweet

## Example response payloads

**GET /2/users/by/username/{username}**

```json
{
  "data": { "id": "2244994945", "name": "Twitter Dev", "username": "TwitterDev" }
}
```

**GET /2/users/{id}/tweets** (truncated)

```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "1760000000000000000",
      "text": "RT @someone: ‚Ä¶",
      "referenced_tweets": [{ "type": "retweeted", "id": "1759999999999999999" }],
      "created_at": "2025-01-15T09:10:11.000Z"
    }
  ],
  "meta": { "result_count": 20 }
}
```

**DELETE /2/users/{id}/retweets/{tweet_id}**

```json
{ "data": { "retweeted": false } }
```

## Use cases

* **Brand hygiene:** Auto-unretweet promos after 48‚Äì72h.
* **Campaign cadence:** Remove event retweets once the event ends.
* **Feed freshness:** Clear low-priority retweets on a rolling basis.

## How to set up

1. Open **CONFIG (Set Fields)** and replace placeholders:

   * `target_username = "your_handle"`
   * `max_results = 100` (per fetch)
   * `batch_delay_minutes = 2` (throttle between batches)
2. Connect X/Twitter credentials in n8n (no keys hard-coded in HTTP nodes).
3. Run once with small values, verify logs, then enable the schedule.

> Optional enhancements: add a **dead-letter path** (Error Trigger ‚Üí Set ‚Üí Sheets/Email/Slack) and a **notification node** (e.g., Slack) for execution feedback.

workflow.name: Automated Retweet Cleanup for X Accounts with Scheduling

nodes.name: TRIGGER | Schedule (09:00 server time)
nodes.notes: Runs daily at 09:00 (server timezone). Adjust cadence as needed.

nodes.name: CONFIG | User Variables (Set Fields)
nodes.notes: Centralizes user-editable variables for easy setup.

nodes.name: FETCH | Get user ID by username (X API)
nodes.notes: Resolves @handle ‚Üí user.id via X API. Uses OAuth2 Credentials (no tokens in node).

nodes.name: FETCH | Latest tweets (X API)
nodes.notes: Fetches recent tweets for the user. Includes fields to detect retweets.

nodes.name: SPLIT | One item per tweet
nodes.notes: Converts the tweets array into one item per tweet.

nodes.name: IF | Is retweet?
nodes.notes: Continue only when the first referenced_tweet is of type 'retweeted'.

nodes.name: LOOP | Split in batches (rate-limit friendly)
nodes.notes: Processes items in small batches to respect API limits.

nodes.name: SEND | Unretweet (delete retweet)
nodes.notes: Deletes YOUR retweet; the original tweet remains.

parameters.content:
## Who‚Äôs it for
Social media managers, creators, and brand accounts that rely on retweets for reach but want an automated, hands-off cleanup after campaigns to keep profiles tidy and on-brand.

## What it does / How it works
The workflow runs on a schedule, resolves your handle to a user ID, fetches recent tweets, filters retweets only, and unretweets them safely with batching and delays to respect rate limits. A dedicated CONFIG (Set Fields) node centralizes variables like target_username, max_results, and batch_delay_minutes, so you can adjust behavior without touching logic.

## Use cases
- Brand hygiene: Auto-unretweet promos after 48‚Äì72h.
- Campaign cadence: Remove event retweets once the event ends.
- Feed freshness: Clear low-priority retweets on a rolling basis.

## How to set up
1) Open CONFIG (Set Fields) and replace placeholders: { "target_username": "yourhandle", "max_results": 50, "batch_delay_minutes": 1 }
2) In HTTP/Twitter nodes, assign your X (Twitter) OAuth2 credentials (never paste tokens into nodes).
3) Adjust the schedule and run a test, then enable.

## Requirements
- n8n (cloud/self-hosted)
- X developer app with OAuth2 + permissions to read tweets and delete your retweets

## How to customize
- Raise max_results (up to 100) or change the schedule (cron/interval).
- Modify the IF condition to target replies/quotes.
- Add logging/notifications (Slack/Email) after each unretweet.

**Security:** No hardcoded API keys. Use Credentials. Keep delay ‚â• 1 minute.

## API endpoints used
- **GET /2/users/by/username/{username}**
- **GET /2/users/{id}/tweets** with `tweet.fields=created_at,referenced_tweets`

### Example: GET /2/users/by/username/{username}
```json
{
  "data": { "id": "2244994945", "name": "Twitter Dev", "username": "TwitterDev" }
}
```

### Example: GET /2/users/{id}/tweets (truncated)
```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "1760000000000000000",
      "text": "RT @someone: ‚Ä¶",
      "referenced_tweets": [{ "type": "retweeted", "id": "1759999999999999999" }],
      "created_at": "2025-01-15T09:10:11.000Z"
    }
  ],
  "meta": { "result_count": 20 }
}
```

## Quick setup
- Open **CONFIG (Set Fields)** and fill: `target_username`, `max_results`, `batch_delay_minutes`.
- Assign **X OAuth2** credentials in HTTP/Twitter nodes.
- Run once with a sample; then enable.

## Rules & customization
- Change schedule cadence in **TRIGGER**.
- Adjust `max_results` up to 100.
- Edit IF for replies/quotes.
- Add **ON FAIL** routing (dead letter) + Slack/Email.

## Troubleshooting
- 401/403 ‚Üí credential scopes or expired token.
- 404 ‚Üí invalid tweet_id or missing permission.
- 429 ‚Üí add **Wait** / increase delay; consider smaller batches.

## TRIGGER | Schedule
- Runs daily at 09:00 server time.
- Change cadence: cron or interval.
- Testing tips: run once manually to push a sample through the whole pipeline.

**Output:** emits a single empty item to start the flow.
**Failure modes:** none (but cron misconfig = no runs).

## CONFIG | User Variables (Set Fields)
Centralizes user-editable fields.

**Fields**
- `target_username` (string) ‚Äî your X handle without `@`.
- `max_results` (number) ‚Äî tweets to fetch (‚â§100).
- `batch_delay_minutes` (number) ‚Äî delay between API calls.

**Output JSON**
```json
{
  "target_username":"yourhandle",
  "max_results":50,
  "batch_delay_minutes":1
}
```
**Tip:** keep all user inputs here to avoid touching logic nodes.

## FETCH | Get user ID by username (HTTP)
**Purpose:** Resolve `@handle` ‚Üí `user.id` via X API.

**Auth:** OAuth2 (Credentials). No tokens in node.
**Request:** `GET /2/users/by/username/{handle}`
**Output shape:**
```json
{ "data": { "id": "123", "username": "yourhandle" } }
```
**Common errors:**
- 401/403 ‚Üí invalid/expired OAuth2.
- 404 ‚Üí handle not found or suspended.
**Next:** feeds `data.id` to Fetch Tweets.

## FETCH | Latest tweets (HTTP)
**Purpose:** Pull recent tweets for the resolved user.

**Query params:**
- `max_results` ‚Üê from CONFIG
- `tweet.fields=created_at,referenced_tweets` (retweet detection)

**Output shape (truncated):**
```json
{ "data": [ {"id":"...","referenced_tweets":[{"type":"retweeted"}]} ] }
```
**Edge cases:** empty `data` array; pagination not enabled in this template.
**Next:** passes array to SPLIT.

## SPLIT | One item per tweet
**Purpose:** Convert list response to single items per tweet.

**Input field:** `data`
**Output:** each item = one tweet (enables per-item filtering & actions).
**Tip:** If API changes payload keys, update `fieldToSplitOut`.

## IF | Is retweet?
**Condition:**
`$json.referenced_tweets ? $json.referenced_tweets[0].type : ''` equals `retweeted`.

**True path:** retweets only ‚Üí proceed to LOOP.
**False path:** non-retweets are dropped.
**Edge cases:** missing `referenced_tweets` ‚Üí false branch.
**Customize:** change to replies/quotes by checking `type`.

## LOOP | Split in batches
**Purpose:** Respect rate limits by chunking.

**Behavior:** iterates through items in small groups.
**Tip:** combine with WAIT for pacing; add error routing if needed.
**Failure:** on API failure, downstream node can push to dead-letter (not included by default).

## SEND | Unretweet (delete retweet)
**Purpose:** Delete YOUR retweet only.

**Node:** Twitter ‚Üí operation: `delete`
**Input:** `tweetDeleteId = $json.id`
**Note:** original author‚Äôs tweet remains intact.
**Auth:** Twitter Credential (OAuth2) selected in node.
**Errors:** 404 when `id` is not a retweet; 403 without write scope.

## WAIT | Delay between API calls
**Purpose:** Space out requests to avoid 429 responses.

**Delay:** uses `batch_delay_minutes` from CONFIG.
**Recommendation:** keep ‚â• 1 minute. Increase during heavy cleanup.
**Alternative:** Use Wait ‚Üí `seconds` for finer control if needed.

## Data flow
TRIGGER ‚Üí CONFIG ‚Üí GET USER ‚Üí FETCH TWEETS ‚Üí SPLIT ‚Üí IF RT ‚Üí LOOP ‚Üí UNRETWEET ‚Üí WAIT ‚Üí LOOP

**Customize hooks:**
- Add LOG node after UNRETWEET
- Add ON FAIL branch from LOOP/UNRETWEET to Sheet/Slack
- Extend IF for keyword/author filters in a prior ENRICH node

Notify path: UNRETWEET ‚Üí LOG ‚Üí Slack (optional)
Error path: Error Trigger ‚Üí DLQ Set ‚Üí (Sheets/Email/Slack)

nodes.name: NOTIFY | Slack (optional)
nodes.notes: Optional: Send a Slack message after each unretweet. Set credentials and channel.

nodes.name: DLQ | Format error (Set)
nodes.notes: Formats an error record for a dead-letter destination (e.g., Google Sheets, Email, or Slack).

parameters.content:
## Dead-letter & notifications (optional)
- **Error Trigger** captures runtime errors and forwards to `DLQ | Format error (Set)`.
- From there, connect to Google Sheets/Email/Slack to persist and alert.
- **Notify path**: after `SEND | Unretweet`, a log message is built and can be sent to Slack.

**Tip:** Use this to audit API failures (403/404/429) and track actions.

## API endpoints (reference)
- `GET https://api.twitter.com/2/users/by/username/{username}` ‚Üí resolve user id
- `GET https://api.twitter.com/2/users/{id}/tweets?tweet.fields=created_at,referenced_tweets` ‚Üí list tweets

**Response payloads** are shown in the yellow master sticky.

main.node: FETCH | Get user ID by username (X API)

data.details: In n8n, when a workflow execution fails, it can start another workflow. This second workflow can be any arbitrary workflow on your n8n instance. Use the Error Trigger node as your Trigger in the Error workflow.

generic.label: Creating Error Workflows in n8n

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
